In the neighbourhood of the AEgean the Oarian pirates and the Ionian traders were as enterprising as themselves, and one after another their factories had to be deserted, or fell into their rivals’ hands, but in the West they came only into eontact with less civilised races, who had no navy on their sea-s, and felt little jealousy of the modest settlements upon their coasts. First they planted the important town of Utica, and coasting thence they pushed across to GadeS, where, attracted by the mines and other wealth of Southern Spain—the Tarsis of traditional fancy— they made a chain of factories and forts along the ’ shores up to and even beyond the Pyrenees‚ not forgetting to gain a foothold upon the neighbouring islands, and Sardinia above all. But rapid as was the progress of these colonies, they were all of them eclipsed by the brilliant foi-tunes of a younger sister.
